title: 112_hr3484
content: The Act is titled the "Travel Regional Investment Partnership Act" and includes findings. The "Travel Regional Investment Partnership Act" acknowledges the significance of travel and tourism, highlighting its economic impact. The industry employs millions of Americans, contributes to the GDP, and generates substantial expenditures. However, there have been job losses and declines in tourism output in recent years. The travel and tourism industry generates $1.3 trillion in total expenditures. Job losses and declines in tourism output were observed in 2009. Public-private partnerships are underutilized but can promote domestic tourism growth. SEC. 3. DOMESTIC REGIONAL TOURISM GRANT PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a grant program through the Office of Travel and Tourism Industries to promote domestic regional tourism growth. Grants will range from $100,000 to $1,000,000 and can be awarded to State tourism offices, local destination marketing organizations, and partnerships between State or local entities. Grants under this program range from $100,000 to $1,000,000 and are available to State tourism offices, local destination marketing organizations, and partnerships between government entities and tourism organizations. Regional diversity is considered in grant awards, with priority given to regions with low tourism marketing contributions. The Secretary may prioritize regions with low tourism marketing contributions, maintain regional diversity, and benefit rural destinations when awarding grants for promoting domestic tourism growth and creating new markets. The Secretary may prioritize regions with low tourism marketing contributions, maintain regional diversity, and benefit rural destinations when awarding grants for promoting domestic tourism growth and creating new markets. Grants awarded under this section may be used to promote domestic regional tourism growth and create new domestic tourism markets through an application process outlined by the Secretary. The application process for grants under this section requires eligible entities to submit an application to the Secretary with a description of tourist promotion activities to be funded and details of partnerships with state or local governments for local tourism. Each application for grants must include a description of tourist promotion activities and details of partnerships with state or local governments for local tourism. State or local government and local tourism entities must provide a list of specific tourist entities partnered with, details of the partnership agreement, and how the partnership will increase regional tourism. The partnership agreement must include specific details on how it will increase regional tourism and positively impact job creation in the relevant domestic region. Non-federal funds are subject to a matching requirement. The partnership agreement must detail the positive impact on job creation in the region. Grant recipients must provide non-federal matching funds in cash or in-kind. As a condition for receiving a grant, the recipient must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to the grant amount, with no more than 25% in in-kind contributions. Reports are due six months after grants are awarded. In-kind donations for non-Federal matching funds are limited to 25%. The Secretary must report travel-related expenditures, tax receipts, and employment generated by grants. The Secretary must report travel-related expenditures, tax receipts, and employment generated by grants awarded under this section. Definitions include "local tourist entity" and "Secretary." Authorization of appropriations is provided for the first 5 fiscal years. Authorization of $10,000,000 for grants under this section for the first 5 fiscal years after enactment.
